Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Production and Economic Exchange in Strengthening Social Bonds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Drs. Urban and Schortman of Kenyon College, together with specialists in material analyses, will study how people forged ancient social relations as they made, exchanged, and used ceramic containers. Students of the past tend to see interpersonal relations as organized within and across territorially nested units such as households, realms, and empires. Consequently, prehistory is populated with spatially defined entities that resemble those one is familiar with today. Archaeologists have contributed to this vision of the past and are uniquely positioned to challenge it. Focusing on who fabricated, exchanged, and used specific items, archaeologists can describe the overlapping social networks made tangible through these highlighted processes. This provides insight into how people employed objects to ally with, and differentiate themselves from, those living in a variety of locales. The past then emerges as a dynamic field of ever-changing social relations mediated through the use of diverse objects, all operating with a fine disregard for borders. These dealings constitute the roots of the present day globalizing world, a history of shifting social, economic, and political relations operating on multiple spatial scales that can only be understood through archaeology. The concepts developed through such studies can be fruitfully applied to understand social and spatial organization in many regions today.

Urban and Schortman's research within three adjoining valleys in northwestern Honduras reveals that the basins' residents during the 7th through 10th centuries AD all used a distinctive form of jar decorated with the same red-painted designs. These are found everywhere, but are made with different pastes defined by variations in clay colors and textures. Such distinct vessel fabrics may point to their divergent origins within the ceramic workshops uncovered at three sites, one in each valley. Occupants of these basins might, therefore, have participated in an extensive social web expressed through the shared symbols that graced red-painted jars. Reconstructing such a web requires analyzing jar fragments with varied pastes recovered at the different manufacturing sites to determine if their chemical and mineral signatures are unique to those workshops. The research will generate new insights on regional prehistory, especially how people living in neighboring areas were variably united and divided through dealings involving the use of material objects. The work also provides opportunities for young Honduran archaeologists to learn the field and analytical techniques they will need to write their country's prehistory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interpersonal interactions are often mediated through the use of objects.  These things are means for accomplishing practical tasks.  They are also charged with meanings that derive from:  how they are used; where, by whom, and how they are made; and with whom they are associated.  Inferring the nature, scale, and significance of ancient social relations, therefore, depends on addressing as many of these issues of function and meaning as possible.

The research just completed grapples with questions of how social relations from CE800-1000 in the neighboring Naco, middle Chamelecon, and lower Cacaulapa valleys of northwest Honduras were constituted through processes of manufacturing and exchanging a ubiquitous class of red-painted jar.  We began the study knowing: each basin was home to a hierarchically structured realm during these years; the domains were ruled by elites residing at their respective capitals of La Sierra, Las Canoas, and El Coyote; each center hosted large pottery workshops; the tools and procedures used in fashioning ceramic vessels, including red-painted jars, differed in each site; and the latter jars were used by people of all ranks across the three basins in daily chores and major social gatherings.  Red-painted jars were thus objects crucial to enacting important interpersonal relations.  What we did not know was whether craftworkers at each production area made the jars used primarily in their respective valleys or if vessels fashioned in one workshop were exchanged with people living in a neighboring realm.  The first scenario implies that social interactions instantiated through the production, exchange, and use of red-painted jars were constrained by political boundaries.  The latter outcome would suggest that these borders were regularly transcended by people who materialized their connections in part by exchanging ceramic containers. 

To begin addressing those issues we subjected 423 fragments (or sherds) from red-painted jars recovered from all known production areas to instrumental neutron activation (INAA), X-ray Fluorescence (XRF), and petrographic analyses; paint from 261 sherds was studied using Laser Ablation-Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometry to determine the recipes used in concocting the red pigments.  INAA and XRF studies sorted the sherds into groups based on their chemical compositions.  Petrographic analyses identified distinct classes marked by particular combinations of minerals identified through microscopic examinations of ceramic clay matrices.  Insofar that pottery made in different places is distinguished by the chemical and mineral components of the clays the artisans used, these assays should link specific pots to particular workshops.  The results to date indicate:

Artisans at La Sierra, Las Canoas, and El Coyote made some versions of the red-painted jars using clay recipes specific to those production areas;

We should therefore be able to describe the networks through which vessels were disseminated to consumers from these sites through such social processes as gift-giving or trade;

Other examples of these jars were found across several manufacturing sites made from clay mixes not unique to any one of them;

Thus, jars made in one workshop were fashioned using different clay recipes and some possibly found their ways to other production loci;

Different recipes were used for creating the red paint but examples of each are noted in all known workshops;

Hence, paints might have been made to the same recipes everywhere or were exchanged ready-made among artisans laboring in different sites;

Processes of pottery manufacture, exchange, and use were largely in the hands of the producers, not elites.

The manufacture, exchange, and use of red-painted jars instantiated multiple overlapping social networks.  One included residents of the three valleys, these connections materialized through their use of jars that are formally and stylistically identical.  Two nets were defined by different ways of making these containers, one centered on La Sierra, the other at Las Canoas (modes of pottery production at El Coyote are unclear).  The exchange of red-painted jars among workshops where similar vessels were being made was apparently motivated by social obligations that involved transferring products whose significance lay more in their sources than functions.  These results strongly suggest that comparable studies of other ceramic artifacts will shed light on the complex social worlds that were created, sustained, and changed through the manufacture, exchange, and use of seemingly quotidian objects.  

Honduran students honed their research skills by participating on this project, helping them to become among the first Hondurans to write their nation’s prehistory.  Some are already incorporating petrographic analyses in their studies, expanding the use of these techniques in an area where comparable studies remain rare.  Educational materials describing regional prehistory and prepared by the PIs will be used to enrich the appreciation of local children for the accomplishments of their ancestors.  Objects once embedded in ancient social transactions are, therefore, serving as means to challenge and encourage students of varied ages to grasp the complexities of past cultures and recall to mind the long-neglected people who used these items.
